snippet: Greece and its European creditors failed to move fast enough to avert a missed $1.8 billion debt payment to the International Monetary Fund.
abstract: Greece misses critical debt payment to International Monetary Fund of 1.5 billion euros, or $1.7 billion, worsening crisis as creditors fail to extend bailout; country is effectively in default and may face more difficult conditions for new aid agreement.

byline.original: By JIM YARDLEY, JAMES KANTER and JACK EWING
byline.contributor: Jim Yardley reported from Athens, James Kanter from Brussels, and Jack Ewing from Frankfurt. Reporting was contributed by Melissa Eddy and Alison Smale from Berlin; Niki Kitsantonis, Dimitris Bounias and Anemona Hartocollis from Athens; and Alissa J. Rubin from Paris.

lead_paragraph: Greece and its European creditors failed to move fast enough to avert a missed $1.8 billion debt payment to the International Monetary Fund.

headline.main: Greece, Missing I.M.F. Payment, Is Called Effectively in Default
headline.print_headline: Greece Misses Payment As European Creditors Fail to Extend Bailout
